articles.title: Astronomers just watched a black hole twist spacetime
articles.description: Astronomers have detected spacetime itself being dragged and twisted by a spinning black hole for the first time. The discovery, seen during a star’s violent destruction, confirms a prediction made over 100 years ago and reveals new clues about how black holes spin and launch jets.

articles.title: The western U.S. Tried to stop wildfires and it backfired
articles.description: Much of the western U.S. is overdue for wildfire, with decades of suppression allowing fuel to build up across millions of hectares. Researchers estimate that 74% of the region is in a fire deficit, meaning far more land needs to burn to restore healthy forest conditions. Catching up would require a

articles.title: Your body feels cold in two different ways
articles.description: Researchers have uncovered that the body uses different molecular systems to sense cold in the skin versus internal organs. This explains why surface chills feel very different from cold experienced deep inside the body.

articles.title: Ottawa not offering incentives to attract Nutrien to build port in Canada, Minister says
articles.description: Steven MacKinnon hopes company will change its mind because of government’s focus on transport infrastructure

articles.title: A hidden T cell switch could make cancer immunotherapy work for more people
articles.description: Scientists have discovered that T cell receptors activate through a hidden spring-like motion that had never been seen before. This breakthrough may help explain why immunotherapy works for some cancers and how it could be improved for others.

articles.title: Scientists spent 10 years chasing a particle that wasn’t there
articles.description: After a decade of painstaking measurements, scientists have delivered a major plot twist in particle physics: a long-hypothesized “mystery particle” likely doesn’t exist. Using the MicroBooNE experiment at Fermilab, researchers analyzed neutrinos from two powerful beams and found no evidence for a s

articles.title: Mystery of King Tut’s jars solved? Yale researchers find opium clues
articles.description: Traces of opium found inside an ancient alabaster vase suggest drug use was common in ancient Egypt, not rare or accidental. The discovery raises the possibility that King Tut’s famous jars once held opiates valued enough to be buried with pharaohs—and stolen by tomb raiders.

articles.description: U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer told members of Congress this week that next year's joint review 'will depend on the successful resolution' of several issues.

articles.title: Silicon Valley Bank collapse renews calls to address disparities impacting entrepreneurs of color
articles.description: When customers at Silicon Valley Bank rushed to withdraw billions of dollars last month, venture capitalist Arlan Hamilton stepped in to help some of the founders of color who panicked about losing access to payroll funds.

articles.title: Big-box stores could help slash emissions and save millions by putting solar panels on roofs. Why aren't more of them doing it?
articles.description: As the US attempts to wean itself off its heavy reliance on fossil fuels and shift to cleaner energy sources, many experts are eyeing a promising solution: your neighborhood big-box stores and shopping malls.

You ran twice as a Conservative, received support from the party, and were elected by constituents who believed they were choosing

articles.title: Not only is Lake Powell's water level plummeting because of drought, its total capacity is shrinking, too
articles.description: Lake Powell, the second-largest human-made reservoir in the US, has lost nearly 7% of its potential storage capacity since 1963, when Glen Canyon Dam was built, a new report shows.
